botanical_details.potentially_harmful: All parts have less toxicity than other species but may cause discomfort if ingested and contact with milky sap may irritate skin and eyes. Wear gloves and other protective equipment when handling
botanical_details.genus: Euphorbia can be annuals, perennials, shrubs or succulents, with milky sap and small flowers held within cupped, often colourful bracts

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grow indoors in a loam-based potting compost with added bark and leaf mould in full light during winter, avoiding any draughts. Minimum temperature of 13-15°C during the flowering season. Flowering and bract colouring is initiated by short winter day-length, occurring naturally in December and January; from November onwards, plants should be put in a dark room after twelve hours of daylight and protected from artificial light sources. Water sparingly during growth and apply a balanced liquid fertiliser every 10-14 days. See Poinsettia cultivation.
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by softwood cuttings in early summer
how_to_grow.pruning: Prune back the plants hard in April, to about 10cm
how_to_grow.pests: Glasshouse red spider mite, glasshouse whitefly and mealybugs may occur
how_to_grow.diseases: May be affected by grey moulds
